column4: my videos that im playing on youtube are being rather sketchy.. is there something i dont have set up properly?
how do i check if i have the accelerated graphics for my nvidea set up right?
theres that collored circle program or something like that...
in a terminal, type the following:  glxinfo | grep direct
whoa.. lots of MISSING GLX display messages
if it says "yes", you're set.  if you want to do a fast 'benchmark' of sorts, you can run glxgears -printfps, to get a quicky 'demo' as it were
then it's not setup, apparently lol.  were you trying the binary blob drivers?
im not sure what ur talking about.. i know i had them set up properly, i think it got messed up when i upgraded to edgy
I recommend the envy script to a lot of people setting up their nvidia drivers. it just works.
does it only set up the nvidea drivers or is it one of those package deals

it will download and install the 'official' drivers from nvidia.com, get all the packages you need to install them properly, and make sure it's setup right.  it's NOT like automatix or anything like that, it doesn't modify package files.  it uses the package manager to make sure it gets setup properly, and gets the .run file direct from nvidia for you.
sounds pretty convenient..
it is.  i ran into one small problem with it ONE TIME, and the 'fix' was just to run the script again.
i installed the package.. did u say i run it through synaptec?

after you download the package, dbl click it, and install it.  once it's on your system, you'll have to switch to a straight terminal (ctrl-f1), and do a sudo envy.  it'll take care of the rest for you.  (it kills x, gdm, etc)
i dont think it worked so well
what happened?
i ran it, and it just went to a black screen, and i could type anything and it wouldnt come out of it.. i hit a CTRL F1 a bunch of times while i was in there and it finally rebooted
i tried to say the instructions before you left... you must've missed 'em :)
ic.. what were the instructions? i just typed sudo envy and let it run

after you install the package, hit ctrl-f1.  log into that terminal.  THEN run sudo envy.  envy will kill off the x windows system, gdm, and any other graphical stuff running.  it will THEN install the driver for you, and offer to restart gdm at the end of the process.
aargh, i am so sorry, i rebound my keys.  ctrl-alt-f1
ok, ill try that
